attributes.action: Give the Environment Agency the funds and freedom to protect English rivers
attributes.background: The Government must reverse years of cuts to Agency budgets, increase charges for polluters, and give the Agency freedom from overly business-friendly Government codes and guidance, so it can pursue and achieve its principal statutory objective to protect and enhance English rivers
attributes.additional_details: Over 10% of freshwater species are threatened with extinction and two thirds are in decline, including salmon. Only 14% of rivers are at good ecological status. 26% of groundwater bodies are at poor status. 40% of rivers suffer pollution from rural areas. Pollution incidents, caused by agriculture and water companies, occur routinely with almost no response from the Agency. Too little monitoring, inspection, enforcement and prosecution of existing pollution law.

government_response.summary: The Government recognises the importance of protecting the natural environment and are investing accordingly to progress our 25 Year Environment Plan and its commitment to clean and plentiful water.
government_response.details:
We are determined to build back greener following the pandemic and progress our 25 Year Environment Plan and its commitment to clean and plentiful water.

The Government recognises the importance of protecting the nation's natural environment and we are investing accordingly.

The Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs Spending Review settlement provides a £4.3 billion cash increase over the rest of this Parliament to £7 billion in 2024-25.

The settlement will allow us to deliver on the Government’s ambitious environmental agenda to halt the decline in species abundance by 2030, achieve Net Zero by 2050, increase resilience to flooding and coastal erosion, support innovation and progress the levelling up agenda.

The settlement delivers against the goals of the 25 Year Environment Plan for nature’s recovery and includes more than £250 million in public investment over three years to include, among other things, tackling nutrient pollution in rivers and streams. 

The Spending Review 2021 also sets a stretching new target to raise at least £500 million in private finance for nature’s recovery every year by 2027 and more than £1 billion a year by 2030.


The Government has taken powers in the Environment Act 2021 to create new, legally-binding targets in four priority areas including water. These new targets will be an important mechanism to drive environmental improvement and meet our ambitious objectives for the water environment in the 25 Year Environment Plan.  

The Act places clear duties on water and sewerage companies to progressively reduce the adverse impacts of discharges from storm overflows and improve transparency of reporting when discharges occur.  

The Environment Agency is driving transparency with 80% of storm overflows now having Event Duration Monitors and all overflows will be monitored by the end of 2023, allowing water companies to report the frequency and duration of spills to the Environment Agency (EA) each year so they can assess compliance. The Environment Agency is acting on new information, suggesting that some water companies in England may indeed not be complying with their permits and a major Environment Agency/Ofwat investigation has been launched.

We are committed to funding the EA to improve the water environment. For example, we are providing additional funding to the EA to increase their farm inspection regime nationwide over the next 18 months. In 2021/2 this includes an expectation of a fourfold increase in farm inspections undertaken nationally with plans to scale up further in 2022/3.

Whilst necessary to uphold basic standards, enforcement of the regulations alone are not sufficient because farmers need advice to understand the risks posed to water by agriculture and funding support where actions beyond regulatory requirements are needed to reduce pollution further.

We are expanding the Catchment Sensitive Farming Programme, almost doubling its funding by providing an additional £17 million over the next three years to enable it to cover 100% of farms in England. Over the last 15 years this programme has been one of the main ways to help farmers tackle pollution which results from manure, fertiliser and soil running off into rivers when it rains. It provides free 1-2-1 advice to farmers to help them reduce water and air pollution through management of nutrients, soils, animals and infrastructure among other things.

Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Habitat Protection - Public inquiry and reform of protections
attributes.background: We need the Government to hold a public inquiry into why so many native species are struggling to survive and why so many are on the verge of extinction, which should result in reform of environmental laws and the Government’s approach to protecting biodiversity.
attributes.additional_details:
Research has found that one in seven species in the UK face extinction, and over 40% of species have experienced decline since 1970.

A full public inquiry could establish the extent to which current laws provide adequate protections for UK species, and the effectiveness of Natural England and Defra, and whether any reforms to current laws and the Government’s wider approach to protecting biodiversity are needed.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Regulate wildlife food so it’s safer for hedgehogs, and all mammals & birds
attributes.background: Shockingly there are currently no regulations on foods sold to be given to wildlife. These foods can contain ingredients that are unsuitable or even harmful.
attributes.additional_details:
We are calling on the Government to regulate these products, so only foods that are suitable for particular animals can be sold as such.
 
Sadly, well-meaning people are buying products labelled as food for particular animals, but they often contain ingredients that can cause the animals that eat it health problems, or even death. We are therefore calling on the government to regulate these products.
 
On 30th July 2020, hedgehogs were added to the Red List for British mammals and classified as vulnerable to extinction. Ensuring food sold as suitable for hedgehogs is safe could help protect this species.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Create a wildlife corridor in place of HS2
attributes.background: This wildlife belt - a 330 mile long stretch of woodlands, hedgerows, wetlands, orchards and meadows - would be the UK's longest nature reserve and have a massive impact on nature recovery across the UK, serving as a conservation area, a critical link between distant habitats and a living seed bank.
attributes.additional_details: We are in the midst of a pandemic, witnessing an extinction of plant and animal species on an unprecedented scale and heading towards a climate catastrophe. Saving lives, protecting and regenerating natural habitats, supporting local economies – all are a matter of urgency and must be given priority over hugely expensive, long term infrastructure projects that are bound to fail the test of time. Further costs, destruction and CO2 emissions needed to complete HS2 works cannot be justified.

attributes.action: Protect our children’s heritage – increase funding for Natural England
attributes.background: Government should restore adequate funding for Natural England to protect nature for the health, well-being and heritage of our children. Since 2008 funding vital for work such as nature recovery, care for sites vital for endangered species, and for landscapes, has been cut by £165 million.
attributes.additional_details:
Natural England is no longer able even to fund urgent work to aid species in danger of extinction. Restoring the budget to 2008 levels only requires the equivalent of 12 days of the current road-building programme, or less than half that earmarked for filling potholes each year.  

At a time of ecological and climate emergency we need to enhance natural capacity to store carbon. We must not abandon the crown jewels of England’s natural heritage and impoverish our present, and our children’s future.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Require Licenses to Keep Chameleons
attributes.background: We wish for the government to regulate chameleons by requiring all owners to obtain a license, like some other exotic animals in the UK do. At the moment, anyone can walk into a pet store and buy one, but studies show that 3 in 10 chameleons will die within their first year of being brought home.
attributes.additional_details: This is because chameleons are one of the more difficult reptiles to keep in captivity, as even a small mistake in their care can result in them being very ill or die. This is concerning because in the wild 36% of species are threatened with extinction, with the main reason being habitat loss, followed by poaching for the global pet trade. We feel introducing licenses will reduce impulse buyers, reduce chameleons dying prematurely in captivity, and decrease the illegal trade of wild chameleons.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Protect Bumblebees and support increased bumblebee numbers
attributes.background: Help to save the diminishing habitats of bees from development and climate change by making bumblebees a protected species under UK law, banning harmful pesticides that kill bees, and providing funding to boost bee numbers across the country.
attributes.additional_details:
As one of the greatest pollinators, bees are essential in keeping the environment healthy and play a vital role in securing stable food supply. 

Without bees, millions of plants could die and the UK could fall further from meeting its environmental targets.

Action must be taken now to save this magnificent species from potential extinction on UK soil.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the shooting of birds for sport
attributes.background: Make a law against the shooting of birds for sport, and any associated activities.
attributes.additional_details: Shooting birds for sport Is barbaric and has no real sense in 2021 or in most opinions, ever. Shooting 'Game' has been ongoing in various countries, and could be contributing to species going extinct or becoming critically endangered. As we all strive every day to do the right thing, to help our natural habitat, whether it be helping to protect the bees, foxes, rabbits, snakes, or any other non-human animal, we must come together to end this old tradition.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Don't close zoos, wildlife parks & rehabilitation centres.
attributes.background: In light of newly considerations re tighter national rules to combat COVID, I urge the government not to consider the closure of zoos, wildlife parks and rehabiltation centres, unless there is verifiable effidence that imcreased infections are linked to visits of such venues.
attributes.additional_details: Zoos, wildlife parks and rehabilitation centres have taken a significant financial impact that is still threatening the continuation of these businesses. These places provide vital contributions to maintain our natural environment, to prevent the extinction of endangered species, to help injured wildlife and educate about our natural world, on which we all rely. Their closure may lead to the death of animals and the loss of many jobs.

attributes.action: Do not remove special protection from vulnerable or near-threatened species
attributes.background: The Government must not remove special protections from species including red squirrels, pine martens, water voles, mountain hares, adders and slow-worms under the Wildlife and Countryside Act, 1981 (WCA), following its current review of the Act, reported in the press in July 2021.
attributes.additional_details: The Government reportedly plans to change the basis on which animals are protected under Schedules 5 and 8 of the WCA to exclude species which are vulnerable (at national or regional level) and near-threatened - see https://jncc.gov.uk/our-work/qqr-7/. It may suit property developers and infrastructure projects to exclude species not in imminent danger of extinction, but this risks harm to species which may be under severe threat, but whose populations have improved slightly.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Work with other Governments on banning trophy hunting
attributes.background: Endangered species and other wild animals are hunted mercilessly worldwide for ‘human entertainment’. A Global Ban on trophy hunting would be a commitment to; discourage the cruel culture of hunting, the exploitation of wild animals and help protect the wild animals that exist today.
attributes.additional_details: Sir David Attenborough revealed-currently, wild animals account for only 4% of the world’s Biomass! The decimation and exploitation of the natural world continues. Merciless trophy hunting involves the brutal killing of wild and endangered species of animals for fun! Queen Mary Uni London (2017) ’Trophy hunting and other activities involving the targeting of high-quality male animals (5% only),can cause the extinction of certain species, when faced with changing environmental conditions. The UK Government should work with other Governments around the world to ban this now.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Scrap HS2 P1 and use the money to pay for fuel bills (and save the country side)
attributes.background: With the cost of living soaring, we propose scrapping HS2 Phase 1 using the money saved to subsidise energy costs. The obscene devastation that has already been done to the countryside can be left to return to the wild and help the species that are facing extinction.
attributes.additional_details:
It is the sensible thing to do. Concentrate on HS2 Phase 2 to help those in the North with infrastructure there where it is needed.
HS2 Phase 1 is a white elephant.

attributes.action: Impose new taxes on private jets to increase investment in renewables
attributes.background: The aviation industry emits 12% of all transport carbon dioxide emissions. We want the Government to impose new taxes on the use of private jets, to try and reduce CO2 emissions and raise funds to invest in renewable energy, green transportation, and electric vehicle infrastructure.
attributes.additional_details: I believe I can speak on behalf of the planet when I say, we have had enough. We desperately need to reduce the level of carbon emissions entering our atmosphere before we are responsible for the mass extinction of almost 90% of marine species, and the millions of individuals at risk from rising sea levels.

attributes.action: Fund the planting of wildflowers along all public green spaces
attributes.background: We would like the Government pledge funding to plant a 1-meter wide strip of wildflowers along the length of every public green space (i.e. playing fields, grass verges etc). Councils would be allocated a grant to achieve this target. The target would be set by the Government.
attributes.additional_details:
The data shows the UK has experienced extinctions and declines in abundance, biomass and distribution of insects. Declines in abundance or distribution have been seen in bees and hoverflies, butterflies and moths, beetles, and freshwater insects. There are a variety of drivers behind insect decline, such as habitat loss, chemical use and climate change, and their impacts differ across habitat, species and time.
 
Source: UK Insect Decline and Extinctions, UK Parliament POST https://researchbriefings.files.parliament.uk/documents/POST-PN-0619/POST-PN-0619.pdf

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Introduce legal requirement for annual licensing on each domestic cat ownership
attributes.background:
An annual renewable licence for each cat with the requirement to;
Microchip 
Owners to have responsibilities for damage to gardens and property caused by their cat.
Keep cats indoors at night (Curfew) 
Prosecution for damage to birds and nests (Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981)
attributes.additional_details:
Cats are destroying wildlife. Many species of bird have become almost extinct. Cats spread deadly disease. Toxoplasmosis can get into vegetables that grow in our gardens when cats defecate on the surrounding soil causing a lifetime incurable parasite that destroys the immune system and can cause death. 

Bring in the laws that they have in Australia such a licence and the requirement to keep cats indoors at night

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Parliament to have a vote on government review of protected species status.
attributes.background: Proposals in their required five yearly review to change the status of protected species under the Wildlife and Countryside Act (WCA) 1981 would reduce protection to only “in imminent danger of extinction”. Parliament must be given time to debate and vote on this damaging proposal.
attributes.additional_details:
The government has published documents about these proposed changes on an obscure website. It is hoping to make these changes, which would severely threaten many of the UK’s rare and endangered species, without proper parliamentary scrutiny.

This would enable developers, road building and rail construction such as HS2 to destroy vulnerable habitats without any accountability or challenge. What Boris Johnston called “the newt counting delays…” Parliament must hold this government to account.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Do not allow UK farmers to use EU banned bee killing pesticides on crops.
attributes.background: The British government wants to allow our UK farmers to use Neonicotinoid Thiamexthoxam on crops. This would kill bees and other pollinators that actually pollinate up-to 3/4 of British crops. Since 1990 the UK has lost 13 species of bee and 35 aren under threat of extinction.
attributes.additional_details: I want government to continue with the EU ban of this dangerous pesticide in order to protect the UK's biodiversity of pollinating species and not put any further pressure on our already fragile environment. Bees and other pollinators are a vital part of our ecosystem and don't need to come under further threat from even more pesticides when the government pledged it would continue the EU ban of this substance.

rejection.details:
You might like to sign the following petitions:

Overturn the decision to allow the use of neonicotinoid pesticides
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/569214

Continue the ban on the use of Neonicotinoids
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/563943

attributes.action: Support zoos, wildlife parks and rehabilitation centres financially in Nov 2020
attributes.background: With a new lockdown starting from 5 Nov 2020, I urge the government to provide financial support to all zoos, wildlife parks and wildlife rehabilitation centres to ensure these places can continue their vital work for endangered species and animals in need of care due to injuries or ill health.
attributes.additional_details: Zoos, wildlife parks and wildlife rehabilitation centres have taken a significant financial impact during the first lockdown. These places provide vital contributions to prevent the extinction of endangered species, to help injured and orphaned wildlife and to educate about our natural world, on which we all rely. Please provide the necessary financial support to ensure these businesses can continue to provide the care for the animals during the 2nd lockdown and the following low income months.

attributes.action: Plant more hedgerows and trees after ripping them out for new housing estates.
attributes.background:
Ensure that any hedgerow or trees that are ripped up for new housing developments, are replaced and planted nearby.
Too many wildlife habitats are being ripped out and concreted over, soon there will be many species struggling to survive or extinct.
attributes.additional_details:
Replacing the trees and hedgerows nearby means species can thrive, aswell as having new housing for the growing population.
Birds will have habitat to return to to build nests, along with other wildlife that relies on hedges and trees to reproduce and live.

attributes.action: Let Zoos open!
attributes.background:
Allow zoos to reopen they are open spaces and can meet the restrictions allow them to open and allow them to continue great conservation work and stop animals from becoming extinct .
LET THE ZOOS OPEN!!
Limited tickets or something
attributes.additional_details: The government needs to do more ... no conservation no animals!! Extinction of air of species will happen quicker because of man !! Again!! Come on parliament !! Do something

attributes.action: Allow Chester Zoo to re-open to the Public
attributes.background: We would like the Government to consider allowing Chester Zoo to re-open as they are a huge outdoor park and have measures in place to comply with social distancing rules. The zoo is a very important educational facility and it's total loss would be devastating to the public and animal conservation.
attributes.additional_details: Chester Zoo is not only a zoo. It is part of worldwide animal conservation and is crucial in preventing the extinction of thousands of endangered species. The zoo is currently experiencing crippling debt due to Coronavirus and have not been given permission to open. Many beaches, parks and other public areas have been flocked by thousands of people as lockdown rules ease but with no way of controlling social distancing. Chester Zoo have measures in place to keep the public safe.

attributes.action: Ban the sale and use of single use barbecues, for the sake of UK nature.
attributes.background:
The Wareham Forest blaze of May 202 is believed to be one of the most devastating forest and heath fires in Dorset in living memory.
The loss to wildlife was immense, and has pushed some species to the brink of extinction.
Single use barbecues must be banned immediately.
attributes.additional_details:
Dorset & Wiltshire Fire and Rescue Service, whose crews from all 50 fire stations from across the service attended the incident at some point over the last week, said 220 hectares – the size of over 230 football pitches – of forest and heathland has been destroyed.
It started on Monday, May 18 through 'social activity' – discarded barbecues, campfires and glass bottles were found at the site.
This incident highlights how devastating and resource intensive heath and forest fires are.

attributes.action: Stop the authorisation and use of pesticides believed to kill bees in the UK.
attributes.background: Stop the emergency authorisation of the use of a bee-killing pesticide - a product containing neonicotinoid thiamethoxam - on sugar beet and other crops in the UK.
attributes.additional_details: The government must stop the use of neonicotinoids in the UK due to the significant environmental risks they pose for bees and other species of insects - particularly pollinators. Insects perform vital roles in the pollination of crops & wildflowers, and nutrient recycling, but have suffered drastic declines. Evidence suggests at least 50% of insects have been lost since 1970, and 41% of insect species are now 'threatened with extinction'. Use of neonicotinoids will only exacerbate this situation.

rejection.details:
You might like to sign the following petitions:

Continue the ban on the use of Neonicotinoids
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/563943

Overturn the decision to allow the use of neonicotinoid pesticides
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/569214

attributes.action: Ban the use of Palm oil in products on sale in the UK.
attributes.background: I want the Government to ban or significantly reduce the use of products containg Palm oil imported and sold in the UK.
attributes.additional_details:
The effects of deforestation are well documented. 

As consumers we are providing a demand for products containing Palm oil which will and is currently destroying the homes and natural habitats of wildlife. 

The Government can help slow down and possibly prevent the extinction of exotic species by seizing our contribution to the demand of Palm oil which is responsible for killing our wildlife and damaging our planet.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/308368

attributes.action: Ban use of shark squalene in any human vaccine production
attributes.background: To legislate to stop pharmaceutical companies from using shark based squalene (liver oil) in vaccine research or to create vaccines and instead only use plant based squalene alternatives which are just as effective.
attributes.additional_details: Many shark species are already critically endangered and in desperate need  of protection not further exploitation. Globally we are already killing 100 million sharks annually, with 75% of these being used to make shark fin soup. This is not sustainable and if it continues many shark species will become extinct in my lifetime. Killing an extra 500,000 sharks to provide squalene for vaccine research is completely unnecessary as sustainable plant based alternatives are available eg from olive oil

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/552673

attributes.action: Increase protection offered to hedgehogs under the Wildlife and Countryside Act
attributes.background: Increase the protection offered to the hedgehog under the Wildlife and Countryside Act by moving it to schedule 5, allowing the level of protection appropriate for such a keystone species in decline.
attributes.additional_details: The hedgehog the has been added to the International Union for the Conservation of Nature’s (IUCN) Red List for British Mammals. We want the government to take action to preserve this species and save it from extinction.

attributes.action: Cats are destroying wildlife.  Many species of bird have become almost extinct.
attributes.background: Bring in cat licensing, for each domestic cat which must be renewed yearly.
attributes.additional_details: Cats are destroying wildlife. Most households have at least one free roaming cat, but many more keep multiple cats. Many species of bird have become almost extinct. Cats spread deadly disease. Toxoplasmosis can get into vegetables that grow in our gardens when cats defecate on the surrounding soil causing a lifetime incurable parasite that destroys the immune system and can cause death. Bring in the laws that they have in Australia.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about the impact on other wildlife of domestic cats, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do.

We could accept a petition calling for the Government to require people who own cats to have a licence, but it would need to be clear what, if any, requirements you wanted to be imposed on owners of cats.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Ban the use of Palm Oil in UK manufactured chocolate.
attributes.background: I would like the Government to speak to UK chocolate manufacturers to eventually stop the use of Palm Oil in chocolate. Using Palm Oil threatens species like orangutans, as their habitats and food sources are getting lost due to deforestation. They will soon go extinct.
attributes.additional_details: I would like the Government to do this as it is not right to kill endangered animal’s habitats. It is possible to manufacture chocolate without Palm Oil as some less popular brands do it. If we loose these animals due to our diets, then we will never get them back. This is our one chance to save endangered animals, and we need to act now. Palm Oil is a product used in food items for taste, and is usually unhealthy food. This is our chance to turn the environment around, and show that we care.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/308368

attributes.action: Allow Zoos to re-open in July
attributes.background: Zoos are running out of money. Some are having to choose which animals will die as they can’t afford to feed them all. Zoos can easily enforce social distancing as they are mostly outdoors. Open them please.
attributes.additional_details: As we face the sixth mass-extinction, zoos play an important role in species preservation. They cannot afford to feed their animals without funding. Please allow them to re-open with suitable guidelines.

rejection.details:
On 10 June the Prime Minister announced that zoos would be able to reopen from 15 June: https://www.gov.uk/government/speeches/pm-statement-at-the-coronavirus-press-conference-10-june-2020  

The Government's list of businesses that are allowed to open now states that outdoor areas of, zoos, safari parks, wildlife centres and other animal attractions are all allowed to open: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/further-businesses-and-premises-to-close/further-businesses-and-premises-to-close-guidance  

Since you started your petition the Government has also announced £100 million rescue package for England’s zoos and aquariums: https://www.gov.uk/government/news/100-million-rescue-package-for-englands-zoos-and-aquariums
